rawContent:
Gonna ruffle some $TSLA feathers here.  

But whatever, its twitter. And I'm happy to be proven wrong.

Tesla is a cool company with an awesome product.

But, be very wary of narratives vs. facts.

I've been told time and time again that Tesla's true optionality is outside of cars.  With software, FSD, batteries, solar and green energy.

Auto makes up >85% of top line sales.  It is what it is.  The numbers are gravity which bring you back to reality.

Forward looking narratives and an investment thesis rooted in an optimistic future is great.  But, it needs to be grounded in fundamentals.  End rant.  Open to counter points, learning more and being open minded if you have anything you think I'm getting wrong.

Red = total auto revenues
blue = energy gen + storage
orange = share price

Our team met yesterday to talk about Tesla's Q1 results. We are all Tesla owners, as well as $TSLA owners. 

We all agreed that we will make no changes to our strategy for this year. Our conviction has not changed. We believe in Tesla's product and mission more than ever. We will not veer from our 2024 strategy, which is:
- Help educate new owners on how to best optimize their Tesla ownership
- Increase R&D spend, continue development of 30 new products for 2024
- Open store #4 in Taiwan
- Open our first international store location (looking...)
- Work with the most informative creators in the space
- Meme the haters

In hardware there are two types of engineers.  A group that likes R&D and a group that wants to ship product.   I only hire engineers that want to ship.  Tesla has produced engineers that are fixated on shipping. Apple is an interesting mix. There are a lot of Apple engineers that want to ship but Apple has also created a playground for people to just play, never ship, and be rewarded for it.

Rough quarter for Tesla.

That said, we just bought a new Model Y and the product is amazing quality now and its AI is finally getting to the place where I hoped it would be when I first bought mine six years ago. 

Elon's investments in X don't yet make sense to most people and his politics have turned off many, particularly in cities, which are more liberal. 

That said, I'm considering investing more. 

Why?

Its AI lead is about to be more and more apparent. This will lead to more and more consumers who want its products. 

And that AI lead will start to matter here in the next 18 months too, as Grok 1.5 is quite accurate, I hear, and will just keep getting better and better and will help X's developers fix the many issues that still exist (like why we can't automatically get rid of bots, yesterday alone I blocked hundreds).

Investors are made, not when everything is exciting and growing fast, but when all the shit hits the fan and things aren't going well.

In 1999 Amazon was $112. In 2000 it went down to $6 when everything else was going bankrupt. 

Did you buy? Almost no one did, my money manager said. In fact, he said every single one of his clients sold Amazon then. 

Investors: how do you mentally prepare for a bad day?

some things for me (I'm on the fence for a model Y):

- FSD is a primary benefit of a Tesla but 12k is way too much for it, especially for an incomplete product that you are personally training for them
- $1k extra for whiter interior of same material is too much
- you can't buyout your leased car

Tesla attempts to appeal to a market that prides itself on "feeling smart". But if you actually buy one, there's a high risk you find yourself feeling stupid.  That's a bad setup! Tesla is trying to create a new market. The way to do that is to create such a good deal that people would feel stupid NOT to buy it.

If instead you take every opportunity you can to nickel and dime people in every place you "provide value" (even if it costs you next to nothing), people will feel that and look elsewhere.

Keep in mind that the tradeoff of an EV is:
- Half-hour+ refueling time
- Fewer places on the road you can fuel your car quickly
- Fewer places that can fix your car if something is wrong with it
- $1500+ electrician costs to set up your home to charge your EV quickly
- Shorter ranges

If you ask people to make all of those sacrifices, you have to be exemplary in other ways. The best way to do that is to offer features at no cost when it doesn't cost you anything to add them. 

A normal car company might not do that, but Tesla doesn't get to be a normal car company. They are competing with a mature gas car industry and the problem with EVs is that even the best EV still kind of sucks compared to the utility of a traditional car.

just guessing from my own indecisiveness, but if FSD were 3k and white interior was offered at-cost, you'd have a lot more sales because tesla's primary target market probably should be solar-owning homeowners in the sunny south where the interior of cars get scorching hot and batteries don't get hurt by any cold weather. 

Teslas run the AC even when the car is off to keep cool though, so you're stuck with a car draining its own range to keep cool when a white interior would make that cheaper

Tesla: our first product is going to be expensive no matter how we try not to make it expensive, and if it is going to be expensive, let's build a niche product that is expected to be expensive.

Do people not want Tesla vehicles anymore? I donâ€™t think so. 

People really want the new Model 3 and Cybertruck, but Tesla canâ€™t make enough. These issues will be resolved in the coming quarters.

For better or worse, one outcome of Tesla's routine and rapid product improvement is that we have a dizzying number of permutations of hardware/software in the field.

The engineers that manage this on a daily basis do a heroic job ensuring that it is seamless and safe for customers. The complexity is massive, and not obvious.

The task grows considerably when attempting to ship to millions of cars at once. In such situations, the patience of our customers is one of our most treasured assets.
